section.name: User guide
section.p: Commons-IO contains utility classes, endian classes, line iterator, file filters, file comparators and stream implementations.
For a more detailed descriptions, take a look at the javadocs.

subsection.name: FileUtils
subsection.p: The FileUtils class contains utility methods for working with File objects. These include reading, writing, copying and comparing files.
For example to read an entire file line by line you could use:
subsection.source: File file = new File("/commons/io/project.properties"); List lines = FileUtils.readLines(file, "UTF-8");

section.name: Endian classes
section.p: Different computer architectures adopt different conventions for byte ordering. In so-called "Little Endian" architectures (eg Intel), the low-order byte is stored in memory at the lowest address, and subsequent bytes at higher addresses. For "Big Endian" architectures (eg Motorola), the situation is reversed.

ul.li: The EndianUtils class contains static methods for swapping the Endian-ness of Java primitives and streams.
The SwappedDataInputStream class is an implementation of the DataInput interface. With this, one can read data from files of non-native Endian-ness.

section.name: File filters
section.p:
The org.apache.commons.io.filefilter package defines an interface (IOFileFilter) that combines both java.io.FileFilter and java.io.FilenameFilter. Besides that the package offers a series of ready-to-use implementations of the IOFileFilter interface including implementation that allow you to combine other such filters.
These filters can be used to list files or in FileDialog, for example.
See the filefilter package javadoc for more details.

section.name: File comparators
section.p:
The org.apache.commons.io.comparator package provides a number of java.util.Comparator implementations for java.io.File.
These comparators can be used to sort lists and arrays of files, for example.
See the comparator package javadoc for more details.

section.name: Streams
section.p:
The org.apache.commons.io.input and org.apache.commons.io.output packages contain various useful implementations of streams. These include:
Null output stream - that silently absorbs all data sent to it
Tee output stream - that sends output data to two streams instead of one
Byte array output stream - that is a faster version of the JDK class
Counting streams - that count the number of bytes passed
Proxy streams - that delegate to the correct method in the proxy
Lockable writer - that provides synchronization of writes using a lock file
See the input or output package javadoc for more details.
